conclusion: To determine whether the two cars will collide, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs (v-t graphs) of the car and the truck.
The car's v-t graph (a) shows that its velocity starts at 30 m/s and decreases over time.
The truck's v-t graph (b) shows that its velocity starts at 10 m/s and remains constant over time.

premise: The car's velocity decreases over time, and the truck's velocity remains constant at 10 m/s.
conclusion: The car is decelerating, while the truck maintains a constant speed.

premise: The car starts at 30 m/s and decelerates, while the truck starts at 10 m/s and maintains its speed.
conclusion: The car will initially approach the truck due to its higher initial velocity.

premise: The car's v-t graph shows its velocity decreases to 10 m/s, and the truck's velocity remains constant at 10 m/s.
conclusion: The car and the truck will eventually have the same velocity of 10 m/s.

premise: The car starts 30 meters behind the truck and initially approaches it due to its higher velocity.
conclusion: The car will close the 30-meter gap between itself and the truck.

premise: The car closes the 30-meter gap and eventually reaches the same velocity as the truck.
conclusion: The car will collide with the truck.
